kbl8iYuv.question: A particular METAR states 4 000 m of visibility. This can refer to the visibility of a light on an unlit background. The intesity of this light is how many candelas?

YsCTNi2u.question: Why should the tilt of an Airborne Weather Radar be lowered whilst searching for thunderstorms in high-level cruise flight?

options.text: The greatest reflectivity occurs from wet hail and rain, and these elements exist mainly in the lower levels of a thunderstorm.
The ground clutter enhances the display by automatically turning up the gain and increasing the likelihood of detecting thunderstorm activity.
The greatest reflectivity occurs from dry hail and snow, and these elements exist mainly in the lower levels of a thunderstorm.
The ground clutter is more evident and therefore less likely to be confused with thunderstorm activity.

CUuCTeLP.question: Why should the tilt of an Airborne Weather Radar be lowered whilst searching for thunderstorms in high-level cruise flight?

options.text: The greatest reflectivity occurs from wet hail and rain, and these elements exist mainly in the lower levels of a thunderstorm.
The greatest reflectivity occurs from dry hail and snow, and these elements exist mainly in the lower levels of a thunderstorm.
The greatest reflectivity occurs from dry hail and snow, and these elements exist mainly in the upper levels of a thunderstorm.
The ground clutter enhances the display by automatically turning up the gain and increasing the likelihood of detecting thunderstorm activity.

wLbnB1Zi.question: Why should the tilt of an Airborne Weather Radar be lowered whilst searching for thunderstorms in high-level cruise flight?

options.text: The greatest reflectivity occurs from dry hail and snow, and these elements exist mainly in the lower levels of a thunderstorm.
The greatest reflectivity occurs from wet hail and rain, and these elements exist mainly in the lower levels of a thunderstorm.
The ground clutter enhances the display by automatically turning up the gain and increasing the likelihood of detecting thunderstorm activity.
The ground clutter is more evident and therefore less likely to be confused with thunderstorm activity.

23H7vAGS.question: Which statement about the Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse is correct?

options.text: This pulse is transmitted by the transponder as a result of the pilot pushing the IDENT-button.
This pulse is transmitted automatically every time the transponder responds to a mode A interrogation.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator if it is suspected that responses are received from aircraft which are located in the direction of the side lobes of the interrogator antenna.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator in order to request for identification of a certain aircraft.

gTa52rRk.question: Which statement about the Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse is correct?

options.text: This pulse is transmitted by the transponder as a result of the pilot pushing the IDENT button.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator in order to request for identification of a certain aircraft.
This pulse is transmitted automatically every time the transponder responds to a mode A interrogation.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator if it is suspected that responses are received from aircraft which are located in the direction of the side lobes of the interrogator antenna.

5qpmgKeJ.question: A weather radar, set to the 100 NM scale, shows a squall between 40 NM and 50 NM. By changing the scale to 50 NM, the return on the radar screen should..

options.text: increase in area and move to the top of the screen.
decrease in area and move to the top of the screen.
increase in area and appear nearer to the bottom of the screen.
decrease in area but not change in position on the screen.

g7Ft1h39.question: A frequency of 10 GHz is considered to be the optimum for use in an airborne weather radar system because:

options.text: the larger water droplets will give good echoes and the antenna can be kept relatively small.
less power output is required in the mapping mode.
greater detail can be obtained at the more distant ranges of the smaller water droplets.
static interference is minimised.

dROZHqZT.question: A frequency of airborne weather radar is:

options.text: 9375 MHz
9375 kHz
9375 GHz

6kfFutnX.question: A frequency of airborne weather radar is:

options.text: 9 375 MHz
9 375 GHz
9 375 kHz

YzKxatXs.question: Which of the following cloud types is most readily detected by airborne weather radar?

options.text: cumulus
stratus
cirrocumulus
altostratus

Zt6PlmT4.question: Which statement with respect to interrogation modes is correct?

options.text: Mode S Broadcast will transmit information to all mode S transponders.
Mode S Only all-call will trigger transponder replies of all mode A/C/S transponders.
Intermode A/C/S all call and Intermode A/C only all call, differ in the pulse spacing used between the P1 and P3 pulse.
Mode S Selective will trigger replies of all mode S transponders. Mode A/C transponders are suppressed.

ZG6QoEit.question: Which of the following is a complete list of airborne weather radar antenna stabilisation axes?

options.text: roll and pitch
roll, pitch and yaw
pitch and yaw
roll and yaw

LrWfAXzY.question: What should be considered when lined up on the departure runway and there are thunderstorms in the vicinity?

options.text: The radar should be tilted up (UP) (rotary switch 2) to check for any significant precipitation on the climb-out path.
The ground clutter suppression (GND CTLR SPRS) switch should be set to OFF to eliminate confusion with weather returns.
The gain control (rotary switch 3) should be set to minimum (MIN) to ensure that all returns are displayed.
The radar should be tilted down (DN) (rotary switch 2) to ensure ground returns are displayed to verify that the system is working.

doAfsoPX.question: A young adult interested in becoming a pilot is invited into the cockpit. They are interested in the weather radar and ask the pilot why there is a tilt knob on the control unit. The pilot replies that this to control the upwards and downwards tilt of the antenna, as required for the two main tasks of the radar, which are...

options.text: detecting significant weather and ground mapping.
detecting thunderstorms and turbulence.
detecting turbulence and functioning in WX+T mode.
ground mapping and controlling the gain of the beam.

kpJ41aZd.question:
(For this question use Annex 062-600164).  
  The pictures in the Annex show an aircraft’s position in relation to thunderstorm cells, and the image of the pilot’s radar. To detect the "blind alley" the pilot should..

options.text: increase the range setting of the radar.
initiate a steep climb.
switch over from normal to weather mode.
select the cosecant square beam for better alley detection.

PkQlbRRB.question: Which of the following data can be shown on an ATC display system? - Flight number / call sign - Pressure altitude - Radio altitude - Autopilot modes - Ground speed

options.text: 1, 2 and 5 only
3, 4 and 5 only

XTX8JJFB.question: Which radar system can be used to detect aircraft that are not equipped with an operating transponder in flight?

options.text: Primary Surveillance Radar (PSR)
Active Transponder (AT)Radar System
Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR)
Multilateral Surveillance (MLAT) Radar System

n1qEyseM.question: Which radar system can be used to detect aircraft that are not equipped with an operating transponder in flight?

options.text: Primary Surveillance Radar (PSR)
Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR)
Multilateral Surveillance (MLAT) Radar System
Active Transponder (AT) Radar System

AArWDDPy.question: Which one of the following switch positions should be used when selecting a code on the transponder?

options.text: STBY (Standby).
IDENT (Identification).
OFF
NORMAL

2Tyj7yqE.question: Which of the following statements in reference to the display of aircraft on a primary ATC radar is correct?

options.text: Both the range and bearing to the aircraft can be estimated simultaneously.
Both the range and bearing to the aircraft can be estimated but NOT simultaneously.
Only the bearing to the aircraft can be estimated.
Only the range to the aircraft can be estimated.

mpsVay1D.question: Why is a secondary radar display screen free of storm clutter?

options.text: Echo returns are not used in secondary radar.
A moving target indicator facility suppresses the display of static or near-static returns.
The frequencies used are too low to give returns from moisture sources.
The frequencies used are too high to give returns from moisture sources.

3xcHisw6.question: Why is a secondary radar display screen free of storm clutter?

options.text: The principle of echo return is not used in secondary radar.
The frequencies employed are too high to give returns from moisture sources.
The frequencies employed are too low to give returns from moisture sources.
A moving target indicator facility suppresses the display of static or near static returns.

PAxqBKAj.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of a secondary radar system when compared to a primary radar system?

options.text: The required power of transmission from the ground equipment is reduced.
The relatively small ground antenna transmits no side lobes, thus eliminating the danger of false replies from the airborne transponder.
Possibility of obtaining speed information for aircraft within range.
Is not limited to line of sight.

DmEKbB7j.question: Why should Airborne Weather Radar (AWR) systems be used with extreme caution when on the ground?

options.text: People could be exposed to Super High Frequency (SHF) radiation which, if absorbed in large enough amounts, can lead to tissue damage.
The intense returns from the ground and surrounding terrain will not allow accurate identification of potentially hazardous weather when lined up for departure.
The radar antenna can be easily damaged during ground-taxi manoeuvres (especially on uneven taxiways).
The radar system may overheat and shut down due to the intensity of the returns from the ground, buildings, and surrounding terrain.

An2onUEa.question: A transponder set to Mode A/C is responding to an intermode radar that is capable of interrogating modes A, C and S. What does the operating mode of the transponder depend on?

options.text: The time between paired interrogation pulses.
The repetition frequency of pulse pairs in the interrogation signal.
The carrier wave frequency of the interrogation signal.
The length of the interrogation pulse.

5gxhqSze.question: You are flying in an area with several CB/TS. You are flying at FL330. What is the best course of action regarding the AWR?

options.text: tilt down because the ice crystals do NOT reflect anything at this altitude.
tilt up to see how high the cloud tops are in order to fly over it with a suitable margin.
tilt up in order to see the “holes” to fly through in between thunderstorms.
tilt down to account for the curvature of the earth.

rUtJvf9g.question: A secondary radar can provide up to 4 096 different codes. These 4 096 codes can be used in:

options.text: all modes.
mode S only.
mode A only.
mode C only.

2N2iKEeh.question: A pilot wishes to cross-check the position of the aircraft using the airborne weather radar (AWR). This can be achieved by:

options.text: Setting the mapping mode to obtain magnetic bearing from the aircraft to suitable echoes on the display.
Comparing the DR position with a suitable point on the VFR chart using the heading and distance from the AWR display.
A suitable echo on the display to obtain relative bearing and distance and then plot a true bearing on the chart.
Echoes from a suitable point, such as a build-up area to obtain a fix.

UEF8QwRj.question: A Mode C-transponder is able to report the pressure altitude in:

options.text: 100 ft increments.
25 ft increments.
100 m increments.
50 m increments.

70VAWReX.question: Which statement is correct regarding the airborne weather radar and its autotilt function:

options.text: It adjusts its tilt according to the altitude.
It adjusts its tilt according to the attitude.
It adjusts its tilt according to the bank angle.
It adjusts its tilt on the ground to avoid harming ground personnel.

iDbU2NRb.question: A radar facility transmitting at a Pulse Recurrence Frequency (PRF) of 1200 pulses/second will have a maximum unambiguous range of approximately...

options.text: 67 NM.
27 NM.

9g95kfZI.question: With reference to Mode S transponders, which statement is correct? The reported altitude data...

options.text: could be accurate to 25 ft resolution but it is dependent on the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.
must be accurate to 25 ft resolution and be dependent on the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.
must be accurate to 100 ft resolution and be independent of the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.
could be accurate to 25 ft resolution and is independent of the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.

I6Mqcbxf.question: Why should the tilt of an Airborne Weather Radar system (without auto tilt) be changed to a higher setting when descending over terrain?

options.text: If the beam’s tilt remains at the setting used during cruise, the scanning range will be reduced and significant ground clutter may be displayed.
If the beam’s tilt remains at the setting used during cruise, the scanning range will be reduced and the strength of the reflected signals will be weaker.
The higher tilt setting will narrow the beam width, allowing for effective detection of cumulonimbus clouds at shorter range.
The higher tilt setting will keep the beam above the aircraft’s flight path.

SlhAsNeX.question: Why can Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) systems provide ATC with more information than Primary Surveillance Radar (PSR) systems?

options.text: ATC SSR systems can interrogate an aircraft transponder and elicit replies.
ATC SSR systems can reply to an aircraft interrogation and offer to provide the requested information.
As ATC SSR systems continuously interrogate aircraft within range, tracking is uninterrupted.
ATC SSR systems have Moving Target Indicator (MTI) capability, which eliminates ground clutter and allows more aircraft to be tracked.

8aaNKCRq.question: A mode A/C transponder receives a P2 pulse from which the amplitude is larger than that of the P1 and P3 pulse. What is the matter?

options.text: The transponder is located in the direction of one of the side lobes of the interrogator antenna.
The interrogation is only meant for mode S transponders.
The transponder is beyond the usable range of the SSR ground station.
The transponder is located in the direction of the main lobe of the interrogator antenna.

DiVooOg9.question: A primary radar operates on the principle of..

options.text: pulse technique.
transponder interrogation.
phase comparison.
continuous wave transmission.

nWwr0wuD.question: Which of the following phenomena is least likely to be detected by radar?

options.text: Clear air turbulence
Precipitation
Wet snow and turbulence in cloud that has precipitation
Turbulence in cloud that has precipitation

THqJjUaE.question: Which of the following equipment uses primary radar principles?

options.text: Airborne weather radar (AWR)
Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR)
Global Positioning System (GPS)
Distance Measuring Equipment (DME)

WZvpAKwD.question: Which type of radar gives an indication of the shape and, to some extent, the type of aircraft producing a return?

options.text: Aerodrome Surface Movement Radar (ASMR)
Airborne Weather Radar (AWR)
Aerodrome Surveillance Radar
Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR)

DsZJyfZv.question:
Which of the following types of radar equipment operate by means of the pulse technique?
1. Aerodrome Surface Movement Radar2. Airborne Weather Radar3. Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR)4. Aerodrome Surveillance -approach- Radar

options.text: 2, 3 and 4 only
2 and 4 only
1, 2 and 4 only

LwXd87Mu.question: With mode-S each aircraft can be uniquely interrogated and identified by using the...

options.text: 24-bits address code, giving more than 16 million possible codes.
twelve-pulse train, giving 212 possible codes.
Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse.
long (30.25 msec) P3 pulse.

sBNv3Ws9.question: A typical primary pulse radar uses:

options.text: a directional aerial for both transmission and reception.
an omni-directional aerial for transmission and directional aerial for reception.
a directional aerial for transmission and an omni-directional aerial for reception.
a directional aerial for transmission and another one for reception.

AJa6Sh5M.question: A ground radar transmitting at a PRF of 1200 pulses/second will have a maximum unambiguous range of approximately...

options.text: 67 NM.
27 NM.

NUVZkvSI.question: Selection of WX+T mode on rotary switch 1 will help to detect and display areas of..

options.text: turbulence within precipitation by detecting the Doppler shift of the reflected radar signal.
CAT within precipitation by detecting the Doppler shift of the reflected radar signal.
CAT within precipitation by detecting the Doppler shift of the falling droplets.
turbulence within precipitation by detecting the Doppler shift of the falling droplets.

imR4NIrb.question: Your radar has a slotted planar array. Which functions can it perform?

options.text: Use a cosecant squared beam and tilt down for mapping the ground ahead.
Use cosecant square beam to view mapping function vertically down.
Use cosecant squared beam to scan in mapping mode.
Omnidirectional mapping.

SGBJGUos.question: Which one of the following Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) codes should be used by aircraft entering airspace from an area where SSR operation has not been required?

zlQcB9cx.question: Which of the following statements describes an advantage of SSR over primary radar?

options.text: SSR allows the identification of a primary radar target by its code and call sign.
SSR allows the identification of aircraft without a working mode A/C/S transponder.
SSR is resistant to garbling and fruiting.
SSR relies only on the reception of a reflected pulse of a radar target.

P4Z3cshm.question: Which of the following inputs does a modern airborne weather radar need to detect wind shear?

options.text: Doppler techniques, inertial data, and air data.
manual gain control in the WX mode.
manual tilt control in the MAP mode.
different wavelengths and beam widths in the WXT mode.

AAerRB9M.question: Which statement relating to the stabilization of airborne weather radar antennae is true?

options.text: They are stabilized with respect to the pitch and roll axis but not with respect to the yaw-axis.
The pilot can choose the axes of stabilization with the system’s stabilization selector switch.
They are stabilized with respect to the pitch, roll, and yaw-axis.
They are stabilized with respect to the yaw-axis, but not with respect to the pitch and roll axis.

OuiPGYaS.question: Which statement relating to the stabilization of airborne weather radar antennas is true?

options.text: They are stabilized with respect to the  pitch and  rollaxis but not with respect to the yaw-axis.
They are stabilized with respect to the pitch, roll, and yaw-axis.
The pilot can choose the axes of stabilization with the systems stabilization selector switch.
They are stabilized with respect to the yaw-axis, but not with respect to the pitch and roll axis.

fridumma.question: Which of the following is correct concerning the setting of tilt angle on a weather radar when it is being used to determine the presence of weather at, or above, your current altitude?

options.text: The tilt angle should be lower when the aircraft is climbing
The tilt angle should be higher when the range is increased
The tilt angle should be higher when the aircraft is climbing
The tilt angle should be lower when the range is increased

kxBtO9AP.question: Which of the following types of radar systems are most suited for short range operation?

options.text: Primary continuous wave.
Secondary continuous wave.
Centimetric pulse.
Millimetric pulse.

aEELyYDJ.question: A Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) sends out an interrogation signal, then receives a...

options.text: reply signal on a different frequency.
reflected signal with Doppler frequency change.
reply signal on the same frequency.
reflected signal on the same frequency.

bmUgC9xI.question: A mode S transponder will respond to...

options.text: SSR and TCAS
TCAS and primary radar
TCAS and ADS-B
SSR and ADS-B

NCSB08ht.question: Which of the following statements is correct about the "gain" knob of an AWR?

options.text: It adjusts the receiver sensitivity in order to achieve optium target acquisition.
It adjusts the brightness of the display.
It is used to adjust antenna tilt.
It can be used to activate the automatic gain control of the AWR.

649ablJJ.question: Which of the follwing codes can an unauthorized aircraft read?

options.text: C/A codes
P codes
Neither C/A nor P codes
P and C/A codes
